instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
This Machine seems to have been dropped more than a few times, came in powering on but with no image on internal display, we did have image on external display, it did have backlight but no image on internal display. After doing some testing we found out that the display connected to a working Mac also has the same issue, BUT when the screen was re-installed back on the dropped Mac that Mac now is stuck at 5V.

Clean board
Does not enter DFU
No light on charger
PPBUS not shorted and 12.3V

I don't know where to take it from here, please be patient.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
If machine was droped, probably broken traces, or solders under BGAs.
First check for knocked off components.

Do you get voltages around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>/8100 PMUs?
<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> is present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Looked all over, no knocked components.
<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> 3.7V
No voltages around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>/8100, some fluctuate a little, but none are stable or higher than 1V
Already gave both PMUs a reflow with good flux but no luck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> LDOs (page 41).
If any missing, check diode mode to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
The ones that are different from a working board are:

<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_MPMU_ISNS</SIGNAL> measures 0.350 vs 0.190 last one is good board but It does have its 3.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL> fluctuates fast under 1V, diode read ok
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> fluctuates fast under 3V, diode read ok
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2SW_CLVR_VDDC1_LDO</SIGNAL> fluctuates fast under 1V, diode read ok
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AON</SIGNAL> fluctuates fast under 3V, diode read ok
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_S2_CLVR_VDDDIG</SIGNAL> fluctuates fast under 1V, diode read ok
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AON</SIGNAL> 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_AON_VCORE_MPMU</SIGNAL> 1.5V

<SIGNAL>NC_PPVOUT_LDO0_MPMU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>NC_PPVOUT_LDO3_MPMU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>NC_PPVOUT_LDO6_MPMU</SIGNAL> not on boardview I assume this are NC No connect.

I also took the time to add and submit the measurements for the community via PDaniels software.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_MPMU_ISNS</SIGNAL> is stable?
If yes, then <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> is suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Yes  <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_MPMU_ISNS</SIGNAL> stable at 3.7V
I will check to see if I can get this IC somewhere

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Ok I got the new chips and have already installed them both <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> but the behavior is the same.

Now I have also noticed that <SIGNAL>PPVDD_DISP_AWAKESW</SIGNAL> is 0.070 and <SIGNAL>PPVDD_SOC_S1</SIGNAL> is 0.040 in diode reading and if I am not mistaking this should be 0.199 and 0.130

For now this has turned into a learning project so lets see if we can get to it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V
threads.message:
Did you check these values before replacing the chips?

Both voltages come out from <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
You can lift corresponding coils and check where the low values remain.
I bet for <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>...
